data.text:
Not sure if you have seen the trend going around but below is the prompt.. I may have changed it a bit ;) 

This was originally for women but wanted to make it more neutral and still have fun with it. 

Upload a selfie and use this prompt in Nano Banana or in the new GPT image generator. 

Create an ultra-realistic 8K Christmas portrait using a 55mm lens with bright, playful holiday lighting. The person is in a whimsical candy-cane themed photoshoot, surrounded by pink giant peppermint decorations, snowy ground, festive trees, and oversized ornaments.
Use their real facial features exactly as they are — do NOT change or alter the face in any way. The makeup is festive glam — winged liner, warm eyeshadow, rosy cheeks, and a bold holiday soft pink lips.
The person wears a sparkly white long-sleeve pants jumpsuit , fitted and shimmering with sequins. The back of the jumpsuit has a scoop-back cut, adding keeping the holiday sparkle. The person is sitting on a white cube block, posing with one leg lifted and crossed, similar to the reference image. The person’s expression is playful and confident, smiling warmly toward the camera.
In their hand, they holds a giant pink-and-white peppermint lollipop prop, resting it over the shoulder in a fun, candy-land pose. Around the person is a fully decorated Christmas set:
• Snowy ground with fluffy artificial snow
• Christmas trees dusted with frost, decorated with pink ornaments and string lights
• Oversized and canes framing whimsical beside them
• A large shiny red Christmas ornament near their feet
Lighting should be bright, clean, and festive, capturing the glimmer of the sequins and the pink candy-themed props. The colors are vibrant reds, whites, and silvers, giving a magical North Pole holiday studio vibe. Emphasize the natural traits of the person in the selfie.

data.text:
Overwhelmed by AI changes? I got you.

Yeah, if you’re feeling buried under the avalanche of new models launching this last 4 weeks like Claude Opus 4.5, Grok 4.1, Gemini 3 Pro, and GPT-5.2, well everyone is, me included. 

The pace is brutal, and the benchmark jargon feels like noisy smart person measurements that mean nothing to an every day user. 

Let’s break it down. 

Main Benchmarks, Simplified:
	•SWE-bench: Tests if AI can fix real software bugs, like spotting and patching glitches in your CRM or app.

	•Terminal-Bench: Checks command-line skills, like running scripts or pulling data from servers.

	•EQ-Bench: Measures emotional smartslike reading tones, empathy in convos.

	•Vending-Bench: Simulates running a business long-term, testing if decisions stay smart over months.

	•ARC-AGI-2: Puzzles for pure reasoning on new problems.

	•GPQA Diamond: Grad-level science questions needing deep knowledge. 

	•LiveCodeBench: Competitive coding for efficient solutions.

	•GDPVal: Real job tasks, beating pros on output.

Why This Matters for GTM Pros: These benchmarks are your efficiency hack. 

High SWE-bench means fewer demo fails from bugs, freeing you to close. 

Strong EQ-Bench turns cold emails warm, boosting replies 20-30%. 

Vending-Bench ensures strategies hold for quarters, not days, like consistent pipeline forecasts. 

ARC-AGI-2 delivers innovative fixes for stuck deals. 

Overall, they predict ROI: less time fixing AI errors, more on revenue drivers like outreach and planning. 

Ignore them, and you’re testing blind; use them to pick tools that compound your edge.

When to use each of the Big 4:

Claude Opus 4.5: The Tech Fixer
	•Strong on SWE-bench (80.9%) and Terminal-Bench (59.3%) that nails bugs and scripts.
	•Use when: Debugging tools mid-deal, automating CRM tweaks, or handling tech support queries. If glitches slow your sales cycle, this speeds it up solo. By far the best for coding, I use for marketing vibe coding. 

Grok 4.1: The People Reader
	•Tops EQ-Bench (#1) with low errors (4.22%) which gets emotional cues spot-on.
	•Use when: Crafting objection-handling emails, personalizing outreach at scale, or scripting calls. For volume GTM like LinkedIn DMs, it lands human-like to lift conversions.

Gemini 3 Pro: The Long-Game Planner
	•Leads Vending-Bench ($5,478) and LiveCodeBench (2,439 Elo) sustains plans, builds efficient code.
	•Use when: Forecasting pipelines over months, automating follow-ups, or optimizing ops tools. If your strategies fizzle mid-quarter, this keeps them tight and executing.

GPT-5.2: The Deep Thinker
	•Crushes ARC-AGI-2 (52.9%) and GDPVal (70.9%) solves novel puzzles, beats experts on tasks.
	•Use when: Brainstorming deal pivots, analyzing markets, or modeling pricing. For complex revenue puzzles like scenario planning, it uncovers edges others miss.

Quite honestly they are all getting so close to each other that it’s like picking Ferrari, Maserati, or Lamborghini. It really comes down to preference.

data.text:
Where Did $37B in Enterprise AI Spending Go?

$19B → Applications (51%)
$18B → Infrastructure (49%)

Our report includes a snapshot of the Enterprise AI ecosystem, mapped across departmental, vertical AI, and infrastructure.

Although coding captures more than half of departmental AI spend at $4 billion, the technology is gaining traction across many enterprise departments: IT operations tools ($700M), marketing platforms ($660M), customer success tools ($630 M). 

AI-native startups are rapidly emerging across every job function, capturing a meaningful share of the $7.3B spent on departmental AI in 2025. https://lnkd.in/gY4nirKH

Whoa. This new GDPval score for GPT-5.2 is a very big deal.

GDPval is probably the most economically relevant measure of AI ability, suggesting that in head-to-head competition with human experts on tasks that require 4-8 hours for a human to do, GPT-5.2 wins 71% of the time as judged by other humans.

Previous best was under 50%.

author.headline: Associate Professor at The Wharton School. Author of Co-Intelligence

data.text:
💥 Today we’re launching GPT 5.2, OpenAI’s most powerful model ever. It’s the most advanced model for coding, professional work, long-running agents.

Moreover, we believe GPT-5.2 is the world’s best model for assisting and accelerating scientists.

We’ve been working closely with scientists across math, physics, biology, and CS to learn where models help – and where they still fall short. With GPT-5.2, the gains are becoming more consistent and reliable: https://lnkd.in/gJDRqygH

GPT 5.2 achieved:
* 92.4% on GPQA Diamond (PhD-level questions across a range of sciences)
* 40.3% on Frontier Math (up from GPT 5.1's 31%  just a month ago!)
* 70.9% on GDPval, assessing professional work across 44 occupations

GPT-5.2 also helped resolve an open problem in statistical learning theory. The model was given the open problem, and solved it directly. @MarkSellke
 verified it and wrote it up—worth a read here! https://lnkd.in/gtYv7qp9

Taken together, these results are early but encouraging signs that frontier models can meaningfully accelerate scientific work – and we’re excited to keep pushing to make them better and more useful across domains.

Want a deep dive into AI agents and how to use AI in companies? Today's podcast guest Elliot Garreffa goes into how he does it with sharing screen and all the goodness.

Most AI projects fail because companies are asking the wrong question.

They ask: "How can AI make this process faster?"

They should ask: "If I had this capability from day one, what process would I design?"

Here's what stood out:
The Real Problem Isn't the Technology

Companies say "we tried ChatGPT for content and it wasn't good"—but that's like judging a car by only using first gear.

The breakthrough happens when you stop bolting AI onto broken processes and start reimagining workflows entirely.

-Why Most POCs Never Scale
Elliot's team spends zero time touching technology in phase one. They talk to the actual teams, map workflows, identify root causes (not symptoms), and build business cases with real projected ROI.
Result? Systems that teams actually use instead of another forgotten pilot program.

-The Autonomy Trap
Fully autonomous AI isn't there yet. The companies winning are building rigid workflows with strategic human checkpoints—not because it slows them down, but because it's the difference between content that converts and content that screams "AI-generated."

His live demo compressed months of SEO agency work into a chat window conversation. Same research depth. Same strategic recommendations. Minutes instead of months.

The episode drops insights on:
-Why your CRO's diagnosis is probably wrong
--The "proof of value" framework that gets executive buy-in
---When to use no-code tools vs. going technical
----How MCPs are changing the game for workflow automation
-----If you're tired of AI projects that look impressive in demos but die in production, this one's worth your time.

data.text:
AI budgets are exploding while AI adoption is 𝘥𝘦𝘤𝘭𝘪𝘯𝘪𝘯𝘨.

Read that again.

88% of executives are increasing AI spend in 2026. Two-thirds investing over $5M annually. Nearly half of tech budgets now directed to AI.

And yet.

Large company AI adoption just dropped from 14% to 12%. 95% of AI pilots at large enterprises are failing. 69% of employees are hiding their AI use from colleagues.

Meanwhile the platform war is getting ugly.

OpenAI declared "Code Red" internally. Google's Gemini 3 hit 650 million users in weeks. Tech giants issued $90 billion in bonds since September to fund AI infrastructure. We're looking at $600 billion in AI capex by 2027.

Companies are spending more, choosing between fewer vendors, and failing to deliver results at scale.

The margin for error in platform selection and AI capability building just collapsed.

I spent 20+ hours synthesizing what's actually happening across enterprise AI adoption, the OpenAI vs Google battle, the trust crisis nobody's talking about, and what GTM leaders need to do in the next 90 days.

It's all in this week's GTM AI Newsletter.

Google just quietly built the most comprehensive AI stack on the planet—and 90% of GTM teams are ignoring it.

Here’s what most people miss:

While everyone debates ChatGPT vs Claude, Google shipped 40+ AI products that already live inside the tools your team uses daily.

Gmail. Docs. Sheets. Meet. Drive. Search. Maps. YouTube.

All connected. All powered by Gemini. All learning from each other.

The math:

$19.99/month gets you:
→ Gemini 3.0 Pro (outperformed GPT-5 Pro on 19/20 benchmarks)
→ AI in every Workspace app
→ NotebookLM Plus for research
→ Image and video generation
→ 2TB storage

That’s less than most teams spend on a single AI tool.

Real GTM use cases delivering results right now:

Pipeline Research
NotebookLM + company 10-Ks + earnings calls + news articles = comprehensive account intelligence in 15 minutes vs 3 hours of manual research.

Meeting Leverage
“Take notes for me” in Meet auto-generates summaries with action items. “Send Gemini to meetings” attends calls you can’t make and reports back.

Content Velocity
Deep Research compiles multi-page reports from Gmail, Drive, and web sources. One prompt. One output. Ready for editing.

Outbound Personalization
Gemini processes prospect LinkedIn profiles, company news, and your CRM notes simultaneously. Personalized sequences at scale without the robotic feel.

Competitive Intel
NotebookLM Audio Overviews turn competitor documentation into 10-minute podcast briefings your team actually consumes during commutes.

Proposal Generation
Workspace Studio agents (just launched) automate the grunt work—pulling CRM data, generating first drafts, routing for approval. 20 million tasks executed in month one of alpha.

The strategic advantage nobody’s talking about:

Google’s AI isn’t just in your browser. It’s on your phone (Pixel), in your home (Nest), on your wrist (Watch), and in your car.

One ecosystem. One subscription. Context that follows you everywhere.

Your competitor is still copying and pasting between 6 different AI tools.

You can have one system that already knows your emails, calendar, documents, and workflow patterns.

The bottom line:

The best AI stack isn’t the one with the highest benchmarks.

It’s the one your team actually uses because it’s already embedded in their workflow.

Google understood the assignment.

data.text:
The AI strategy every revenue leader is copying right now just got exposed as broken.

And the fix is counterintuitive.

New research from Tsinghua University studied how AI systems perform when you add more specialized “agents” working together.

Every vendor is pitching this. More agents. More specialization. More collaboration.

The researchers found the opposite of what the industry is selling.

Quick primer if you’re not deep in the AI weeds:

Single-agent AI → One model doing everything. You ask ChatGPT a question. It answers. One brain. One task.

Multi-agent AI → Multiple AI “agents” with different jobs passing work to each other. One researches. One writes. One critiques. One executes.

Sounds smart. Mirrors how we build human teams.

Here’s where it breaks.

Most multi-agent systems are just bureaucracies.

Fixed workflows.
Predetermined handoffs.
Agent A always passes to Agent B always passes to Agent C.
Same sequence every time.
Regardless of what’s working.

It’s not intelligence. It’s an assembly line nobody’s managing.

The researchers tested something different.

They added a “puppeteer” or central coordinator that watches outcomes and makes real-time decisions.

Which agent should work next?
Who’s actually contributing?
Who should get cut?

The results flipped conventional wisdom.

Finding 1: The system got smaller as it got smarter.

Static approach → Add more agents for more capability
Evolved approach → Concentrate work around 2-3 high-performers

The orchestrator learned that most agents added overhead without value. They got benched.

This is exactly how great deal teams work. You don’t need eight people in every meeting. You need the right two who move things forward.

Finding 2: Feedback loops beat linear handoffs.
Static approach → Work moves A to B to C to done
Evolved approach → Agents circle back, check work, refine, iterate

Real deals don’t move in straight lines either. You loop back to discovery. You revisit pricing. You refine the proposal.

The AI learned to do this on its own.

Finding 3: Speed and quality improved together.

Static approach → Better results require more resources
Evolved approach → Cut waste, tighten coordination, get faster AND better

The assumption that performance costs compute? This research broke it.

The problem isn’t your tools. It’s the absence of orchestration.

The shift I’d be thinking about:

Old question → How many AI capabilities can we add?
New question → How does our system learn what actually works?

Old question → Which tools should we buy?
New question → What’s our orchestration layer?

Old question → How do we integrate everything?
New question → How do we prune what doesn’t contribute?

The companies that figure out orchestration early will compound that advantage.

The ones that keep stacking tools will keep wondering why the investment isn’t showing up in pipeline.

data.text:
Your AI pilots aren't failing because of the technology.. take a wild guess why they fail? Wanna know? Let me send it to you...

It is time for the GTM AI Podcast and newsletter and I was fortunate to interview Ken Roden diving into his doctoral research at Temple University, and what he uncovered should fundamentally change how every GTM leader thinks about AI implementation in 2026.

Ken surveyed 200 professionals with statistically significant findings and the pattern he discovered explains why every headline is screaming about AI pilot failures. But it's not what MIT is telling you. It's not what the consultants are writing case studies about. And it's definitely not what you think.

The real blocker isn't employee resistance. It isn't inadequate technology. It isn't even change management.

I'm not going to spoil the actual finding here because you need to hear Ken walk through the data himself. But I will tell you this: If you're a GTM leader who thinks you understand how your team is using AI right now, you're almost certainly wrong. And that misunderstanding is costing you deals, talent, and competitive positioning every single quarter.

We also unpacked:
→ Why the people who think they're AI experts are often the least competent (and how to fix that) 
→ The "boring" use cases that are saving 20+ hours per week per rep (hint: it's not what's getting VC funding) 
→ Why your most confident AI users might be your biggest liability 
→ The AI Sandwich Model that's actually getting pilots to production 
→ What "AI fatigue" really means and why it's about to hit your team hard 
→ Why GPT-5's "Gronk problem" means you need to diversify your AI stack immediately

This conversation was one of those rare ones where I kept saying "wait, go back to that" because the implications kept cascading. The trust architecture piece alone will change how you think about rolling out AI across your org.

data.text:
Every VC I've talked to in the last 4 months (more than 10 VCs of big names) and 100+ CRO and Revenue leaders says the same thing: "Cut your enablement headcount. AI replaces them."

Here is the problem: They're dead wrong about what enablement actually does.

Last week, another investor told me to eliminate enablement roles. I asked what they thought enablement did. Their answer? "Training, onboarding, updating battle cards."

That's not enablement. That's busywork we got stuck with.

Real enablement is what happens when your sales rep wastes 3 hours finding the right pricing doc. When marketing builds a "game-changing" tool nobody uses. When your $50k AI investment sits at 12% adoption because nobody thought about workflow integration.

We're the ones who spot that your top performer spends 70% of their time on admin work. Who notice your RevOps team built 155 fields but only 8 get used. Who realize your new AI tool contradicts your existing process.

But here's the spicy part: Enablement is dying because we let ourselves get packaged wrong.

We became the LMS managers. The training coordinators. The PowerPoint updaters. And now VCs and Revenue leaders galore think that's all we do.

Meanwhile, companies are failing at AI adoption at an 85% rate (Gartner's number, not mine). Why? No change management. No workflow design. No friction removal.

Exactly what enablement should be doing.

The solution isn't defending a dying brand. It's repackaging what we actually do. Call it AI Ops, GTM Strategy, Revenue Acceleration - I don't care.

Stop fighting for a title that's been poisoned. Start owning the work that actually matters: orchestrating tools, removing friction, driving adoption.

Because while everyone's debating whether enablement has value, someone needs to fix the fact that your sellers spend 33% of their time actually selling.

That someone used to be called enablement. Tomorrow, we'll be called something else.

The work remains critical, I believe in Enablement more now than ever, the problem is how revenue leaders and VCs view the title.

If you're searching for GTM tech this Black Friday, start with these:

Maja and I asked our communities about their favorite B2B GTM tools in 2025 including which were "most impactful" and which are "must try". 195 software GTM leaders weighed in. (And Gemini sorted through 1,000+ open-ended responses 🤯.)

ChatGPT topped the list of most impactful tools with 50 write-ins. They were followed by OG HubSpot (40 write-ins) and breakout unicorn Clay (30 write-ins). This list included tried-and-true tools you're probably familiar with like LinkedIn, Gong, Notion, 6sense, Canva, Figma, Apollo & ZoomInfo.

Things got more interesting on the "must try" list. GTM leaders are trying out vibecoding (Lovable - 2nd, Replit - 5th, Magic Patterns) and AI agents (n8n - 3rd, Relay.app, Dust). Folks are also on the lookout for more & better tooling for advanced GTM plays (see: Clay, Keyplay, Unify).

If the "must try" list is any indication, we're eager to graduate beyond ChatGPT to more advanced AI use cases. But 2025 is still the year of AI experimentation vs. true impact.

article.title: 11/26/25: Why AI Engineers Are Betting Against Unicorns (And What GTM Leaders Should Actually Build Instead)
article.subtitle: Jonathan M K.

resharedPost.text:
I recently caught up with Andreessen Horowitz on GTM in the AI era.

As GTM Engineer at Clay, I'm witnessing how buyers and selling motions are changing & adapting.

Partners Seema Amble and James da Costa summed up these changes really well in their recent post:

"𝘕𝘦𝘦𝘥 𝘧𝘰𝘳 𝘚𝘱𝘦𝘦𝘥 𝘪𝘯 𝘈𝘐 𝘚𝘢𝘭𝘦𝘴: 𝘈𝘐 𝘋𝘰𝘦𝘴𝘯’𝘵 𝘑𝘶𝘴𝘵 𝘊𝘩𝘢𝘯𝘨𝘦 𝘞𝘩𝘢𝘵 𝘠𝘰𝘶 𝘚𝘦𝘭𝘭. 𝘐𝘵 𝘈𝘭𝘴𝘰 𝘊𝘩𝘢𝘯𝘨𝘦𝘴 𝘏𝘰𝘸 𝘠𝘰𝘶 𝘚𝘦𝘭𝘭 𝘐𝘵.”

Some of my favorite, most useful takeaways to think about in GTM: 

💰 𝗧𝗵𝗲𝗿𝗲'𝘀 𝗺𝗼𝗿𝗲 𝗯𝘂𝘆𝗲𝗿𝘀 𝗶𝗻 𝗺𝗮𝗿𝗸𝗲𝘁, 𝗺𝗼𝗿𝗲 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗲𝘁𝗶𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻, 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗹𝗲𝘀𝘀 𝗱𝗶𝗳𝗳𝗲𝗿𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗶𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻.

It's no longer just about "what you do" and its becoming way more important to show "how quickly and reliably you do it it."

⏳  𝗕𝘂𝘆𝗲𝗿𝘀 𝘄𝗮𝗻𝘁 𝗔𝗜 𝗻𝗼𝘄, 𝘁𝗵𝗲𝗿𝗲'𝘀 𝘁𝗼𝗻𝘀 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗙𝗢𝗠𝗢 𝗳𝗿𝗼𝗺 𝗽𝗲𝗲𝗿 𝗮𝗻𝗻𝗼𝘂𝗻𝗰𝗲𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁𝘀.

This means that speed of deployment and value creation needs to be faster than ever.

According to another one a16z's surveys: 𝟳𝟬 𝗽𝗲𝗿𝗰𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗼𝗳 𝗯𝘂𝘆𝗲𝗿𝘀 𝗿𝗲𝗽𝗼𝗿𝘁𝗲𝗱 𝘁𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝘀𝗽𝗲𝗲𝗱 𝗼𝗳 𝗱𝗲𝗽𝗹𝗼𝘆𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝘄𝗮𝘀 𝗮 𝘁𝗼𝗽 𝗳𝗮𝗰𝘁𝗼𝗿 𝘄𝗵𝗲𝗻 𝗲𝗻𝗴𝗮𝗴𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗔𝗜 𝘃𝗲𝗻𝗱𝗼𝗿𝘀.

🔒  𝗧𝗿𝘂𝘀𝘁 𝗵𝗮𝘀 𝗻𝗲𝘄 𝗻𝗲𝗲𝗱𝘀.

Software used to be just a conduit to something else (Airbnb helps you find houses to book), but now tech/AI is the product.

This means that trust needs go from "𝘄𝗲 𝗹𝗼𝗴 𝘄𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝗵𝘂𝗺𝗮𝗻𝘀 𝗱𝗼 𝗼𝗻 𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝘀𝗼𝗳𝘁𝘄𝗮𝗿𝗲" to "𝘄𝗲 𝗱𝗼 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗸 𝗰𝗼𝗿𝗿𝗲𝗰𝘁𝗹𝘆 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗰𝗮𝗻 𝘀𝗵𝗼𝘄 𝗵𝗼𝘄."

📖  𝗕𝘂𝘆𝗲𝗿𝘀 𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝘀𝗲𝗹𝗳 𝗲𝗱𝘂𝗰𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗴𝗼𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗱𝗲𝗲𝗽𝗲𝗿.

You need to come to the table with:

• A stronger, more thought out point of view
• A personalized demo that gets to a 'light bulb' moment faster
• Need to show tangible value earlier (before the traditional POC)

⚙️  𝗦𝗮𝗹𝗲𝘀 𝗿𝗼𝗹𝗲𝘀 𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝗯𝗲𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗺𝗼𝗿𝗲 𝘁𝗲𝗰𝗵𝗻𝗶𝗰𝗮𝗹

"Instead of understanding the people using your software, AEs need to understand the technical details of how agents will actually do the work of humans."

At Clay, we collapsed the AE & Solution Engineering roles to provide a better customer experience and to help with points 1-4. We're called GTM Engineers.

👷‍♀️  𝗙𝗼𝗿𝘄𝗮𝗿𝗱 𝗱𝗲𝗽𝗹𝗼𝘆𝗲𝗱 𝗲𝗻𝗴𝗶𝗻𝗲𝗲𝗿𝘀 𝗵𝗲𝗹𝗽 𝗴𝗲𝘁 𝗰𝘂𝘀𝘁𝗼𝗺𝗲𝗿𝘀 𝘁𝗼 𝘃𝗮𝗹𝘂𝗲 & 𝗳𝗮𝘀𝘁𝗲𝗿 𝗶𝗺𝗽𝗹𝗲𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀.

data.text:
Most people prompt every AI the same way. That’s why their outputs are mediocre.

I’ve tested hundreds of prompts across every major AI platform. The difference between average and exceptional outputs isn’t prompt length. It’s prompt style matched to the tool.

This framework breaks it down:

ChatGPT → Prompt like an instructor.

Start with a role assignment: “Act as a productivity coach.” Define the specific task. Ask for step-by-step action plans with timelines. Specify your desired format—table, outline, bullet list. Request tool recommendations. ChatGPT excels at structured guidance and task planning. Give it constraints and it delivers.

Perplexity → Prompt like a research analyst.

Lead with specific information requests. Include relevant keywords, timeframes, and geographies. Ask for cited sources and reference links for verification. Request trend summaries with citations. Follow up with comparison questions that require data-backed reasoning. Perplexity is built for evidence-based analysis. Treat it like a junior analyst who needs clear research parameters.

Grok → Prompt like a candid friend.

Use conversational tone: “Hey Grok, what do you think about…” Add emotional context. Ask for honest, unfiltered feedback and alternative perspectives. Request comparisons or opposing viewpoints to challenge your assumptions. Ask for common pitfalls and mistakes to avoid. Grok thrives on casual brainstorming and identifying blind spots others miss.

Gemini → Prompt like a project planner.

Explain the overall project goal upfront. Define expected outputs—tasks, subtasks, timelines. Ask about Google Workspace integrations. Request detailed weekly or daily action plans. Ask for dependency breakdowns and milestones. Request formatted outputs like tables and charts. Gemini is optimized for project management and collaborative workflows.

Why this matters:

Each model has a personality bias baked into its training data and architecture. ChatGPT leans toward structured helpfulness. Perplexity toward verification and sourcing. Grok toward irreverence and contrarianism. Gemini toward organizational workflows.

When you fight these tendencies, you get generic outputs.
When you lean into them, you unlock capabilities most users never see.

The tactical shift:

Stop copying prompts between platforms. Start adapting your communication style to each tool’s strengths.

Same question, different framing = dramatically different quality.

One prompt style for all tools is lazy.
Adapted prompting is leverage.

Bain & Company’s AI Playbook: Right Questions, Missing Operating System

Bain nailed the strategy. They completely missed the execution engine that separates winners from optimizers.

What Bain Gets Right

Business transformation framing:
AI as strategic priority, not IT project. Speed over productivity. Fewer bigger bets over scattered pilots.

Data determines everything: 
79% of data foundation leaders expect competitive revenue advantage. True.

Real validation:
Bain’s AI Playbook: Right Questions, Missing Operating System

Bain nailed the strategy. They completely missed the execution engine that separates winners from optimizers.

The Critical Gaps

Every case study shows departmental optimization. Zero methodology for building compound learning systems.

The difference: Tools improve existing work 20-40%. 
Intelligence architecture creates 10x moats through proprietary data capture 
→ specialized models 
→ execution engines competitors cannot replicate.

Bain shows you WHAT to prioritize. Missing: HOW to design systems where every transaction trains models that get smarter, creating compounding advantages.

AGENTIC ORCHESTRATION COMPLETELY ABSENT

Brief mention, zero operational framework. The future isn’t “AI copilots helping humans do current jobs better.”

It’s autonomous agents executing multi-step workflows with human oversight doing fundamentally different work at machine speed.

Where’s the methodology for:

- Decomposing human decisions into AI-executable components
- Orchestrating multi-agent systems across departments
- Building feedback loops that improve model performance
- Creating governance for autonomous execution

NO METHODOLOGY FOR AI-NATIVE DESIGN

“Reimagine workflows” without systematic frameworks for HOW.

Gap: Operational playbooks for transforming human processes into AI-native operations. Prompt architecture that scales. Decision decomposition frameworks. Agent orchestration patterns.

Strategy consultants excel at WHAT and WHY. Execution requires detailed HOW.

## The Bottom Line

This report helps CEOs ask the right questions and avoid common mistakes. It won’t help them build the execution systems that create defensible competitive advantages.

Stop thinking tools. Start thinking intelligence architecture.

The winners aren’t optimizing departments faster. They’re building compound learning systems that capture proprietary data, train specialized models, and execute at speeds competitors cannot match.

data.text:
Amazon: 14,000 layoffs. Verizon: 13,000 layoffs. Both citing AI as a primary driver.

But Yale’s 2025 labor market analysis shows minimal AI-induced job disruption across the broader economy.

What’s actually happening:

Amazon’s cuts follow pandemic overexpansion and bureaucracy reduction. Their AI investments are going into AWS infrastructure and research—reallocation, not elimination.

Verizon’s restructuring stems from T-Mobile competition, declining subscribers, and retail franchising. The “AI-era reskilling fund” is a $20M footnote to a 13% workforce reduction.

Nearly 50,000 U.S. tech job cuts in 2025 referenced AI. But analysts note these decisions are driven by cost structures, competitive pressure, and organizational complexity more than actual automation displacement.

The disconnect: Companies use AI as justification. Labor economists see gradual transformation, not mass replacement.

For GTM leaders: Don’t confuse corporate restructuring narratives with market reality. AI is reshaping how work gets done, but the “employment reset” hasn’t materialized. The opportunity is in strategic deployment, not defensive positioning against phantom displacement.

The companies winning aren’t the ones cutting fastest, they’re the ones investing in AI infrastructure while their competitors rationalize headcount.

data.text:
98% of executives would rather be safe than first.

That was March 2024. MIT Tech Review surveyed 205 C-suite leaders predicting their AI deployment timelines. Now that we’re closing 2025, the prediction accuracy is fascinating.

What they predicted:

- 50% expected full AI deployment across all functions by now
- 90% planned to increase AI readiness spending significantly
- Data quality was the #1 deployment blocker (50% cited)
- Governance and security concerns outweighed speed (45%)

What actually happened:
Most companies are still stuck in pilot purgatory. The ones that broke through didn’t solve for data quality first—they solved for workflow orchestration. The insight engines didn’t win. The execution engines did.

The “safe over first” mentality backfired for most. While companies spent 18 months building perfect data foundations, their competitors shipped imperfect AI that automated real revenue workflows. Turns out buyers don’t care if your data is pristine. They care if your AI books the meeting, writes the follow-up, and moves deals forward.

What I’m seeing now:

- Companies that picked 1-2 high-impact workflows and went deep are seeing 10x ROI
- The data quality problem solved itself through use, not preparation
- Agent swarms handling end-to-end processes beat point solutions by miles
- ROI measurement is still broken—most still measure time saved vs revenue accelerated

Where we got it wrong:
The report said “data liquidity matters more than data volume.” True, but incomplete. Execution velocity matters more than both. The companies winning now didn’t wait for perfect data. They built feedback loops that improved data quality through automated workflows.

If you’re still waiting for AI readiness, you’re already behind. Ship the workflow. Fix the data in production.

data.text:
Boston Consulting Group (BCG) recenter released research on fully autonomous companies, with zero employees, only coordinated AI agents. $116B invested in H1 2025. The timeline is debatable. The implications aren’t.

The AI-Only Advantage

AI model costs drop 10x annually. A sales agent handles prospect research, outreach, and scheduling in seconds, operating 24/7/365, learning from every interaction across all agents simultaneously. No coordination friction. Strategy deploys instantly.

For revenue teams: 70% of a rep’s time goes to activities AI handles today. The cost structure alone creates advantage incumbents can’t match with traditional models.

Where Humans Win

AI creates new constraints faster than it solves old ones:

Curation: When AI floods markets with content, taste becomes the bottleneck. Cultural context and brand identity require human judgment.

Evaluation: AI generates infinite hypotheses but can’t distinguish creative from feasible. Research shows it fails consistently at prioritization. Humans determine which problems merit investment.

Empathy: Trust-sensitive domains—healthcare, education, high-stakes B2B—require genuine human presence. 89% of executives say in-person meetings seal deals. An AI-only insurer struggles when customers need assurance a real company honors promises years later.

Relationship Capital: Decades of accumulated trust can’t be replicated by an entity that can’t shake hands. Incumbents become relationship brokers and guarantors in AI ecosystems.

Messiness: AI does not do well with messiness. Humans are messy, things change all the time in ways that are difficult for the best of machines to predict. Beyond the prediction it’s handling the messiness in a way that is constructive. AI current state still needs help here. 

The Strategic Question

The firms that win aren’t pure AI-only or traditional. They’re AI-first companies that redesign workflows around agents while leveraging human judgment where it compounds advantage.

The question isn’t whether AI-only firms will exist. It’s which new constraints emerge as AI commoditizes current advantages—and whether you’re positioned to solve those constraints or get bypassed.

Revenue leaders: track AI development, pilot agentic tech now, and identify where human capabilities solve emerging constraints in your domain.

Thanks for Michael for the doc.

document.title: BCG Why CEOs should prepare against AI competitors

data.text:
If you're planning to deploy AI agents for sales, customer success, or revenue operations, you need to understand context management. It's the difference between an agent that works and one that forgets critical deal details mid-conversation.

The Problem: 

AI models have context windows which is the amount of conversation history they can "remember" at once. Even GPT-5's 272k token window gets overwhelmed when you're managing multi-turn customer conversations, CRM data, and tool outputs. 

Without proper management, your agent either:
-Loses critical information (forgot the customer's tier, previous commitments, or objections)
--Gets distracted by irrelevant details (yesterday's question derails today's close)
---Slows down and costs more (processing massive, bloated conversation logs)

Two Approaches:
1-Context Trimming (keep last N turns, drop everything else)

Best for: Task-based workflows where each interaction is independent—updating CRM fields, pulling reports, routing tickets

Limitation: Hard amnesia. If turn 8 matters but you only keep 5 turns, it's gone.

2-Context Summarization (compress old conversations into structured summaries)

Best for: Ongoing relationships where history matters—enterprise sales cycles, CSM account management, multi-touch sequences

Limitation: Summarization can lose nuance or introduce errors that compound over time

OpenAI released their SDK Agent workbook so to speak which talks about how to solve this.

What Most Get Wrong:
They treat context like a technical problem, not a workflow design problem. Before choosing trimming vs. summarization, map your actual GTM process:

Does this conversation need to remember commitments from 3 weeks ago? (summarize)

Is each interaction self-contained? (trim)

What's the cost of forgetting vs. the cost of misremembering?

GTM-Specific Reality:
In sales, forgetting a pricing commitment destroys trust. In customer support, losing the troubleshooting history creates repeat work. In SDR workflows, context is often ephemeral because qualification status matters more than conversation history.

The Practical Question:
If you're considering AI agents for your GTM org, ask: "What does this agent need to remember across turns to do its job?" Then engineer your context strategy accordingly. 

Default approaches fail because they assume all conversations have the same memory requirements. They don't.

Most teams implement agents first, then discover context management the hard way, when deals slip because the agent "forgot" key details.

Build your context strategy before you build your agent.

If you want the OpenAI context engineering cookbook, happy to send to you, just comment below that you want the goods.

#AIAgents #GTMStrategy #RevenueOperations #ContextEngineering
